fields.descriptive_line:
Theatrical ensemble of coat, waistcoat, breeches and sword worn by Sir Henry Irving as Doricourt in Mrs Cowley's 'The Belle's Stratagem', at the Lyceum in 1876 under Mrs Bateman's management.
[sword] Thin rapier style sword with separate scabbard (S.2717:5-2010) used by Sir Henry Irving as Doricourt in 'The Belle's Stratagem' (1876)
fields.physical_description:
[coat] 18th century style coat in pewter/grey silk. Ten ornate 'marquisette' buttons at front (not practicable), three at each sleeve, two under the pocket flaps on each side (originally three but central one removed). Two buttons at back vent. Lace cuffs. Long black cotton tapes in waist lining, to be tied round waist to hold coat in place.
[waistcoat] 18th century style waistcoat, pewter/grey silk, striped horizontally with black velvet. Double breasted with 26 self-covered buttons. Two practicable pockets with flaps  Small stand up collar and folded back lapels. Lined with cream cotton sateen. Half belt at back with metal buckle.
[breeches] 18th century style knee breeches of pewter/grey silk, with fall front fastened with two metal buttons at centre and two cloth covered buttons to each side. Nine further metal buttons at waist. Buckle at back of waist band. Fastened at each knee with three self-covered buttons and a metal buckle.
[sword] Thin rapier style sword with separate scabbard (S.2714:5-2010) . Long narrow blade, concave underside, ridged upper side. The blade is plain, but the hilt of the sword is made from metal that has been decoratively moulded. The majority of this decoration is focused on the guard, grip and pommel.
[scabbard] Scabbard. Made from black leather to fit blade of rapier (S.2714:4-2010). A metal fitting has been added at the throat of the scabbard, with a further fitting a little further down. Both have carrying rings attached which were presumably originally used to suspend the scabbard from a sword belt.
fields.dimensions:
[coat] Length: 109.5 cm back of collar to hem, Width: 45.5 cm measured across shoulders, Width: 46 cm measured across chest
[waistcoat] Length: 61 cm maximum length at front, Length: 49.5 cm maximum length at back, Width: 45 cm measured across shoulders, Width: 53 cm measured across chest
[breeches] Length: 78 cm maximum length including waistband, Length: 78 cm outside leg including waistband, Width: 37 cm measured across waist
[sword] Length: 75.25 cm Blade, Length: 15.5 cm Hilt, Length: 75.5 cm total
[scabbard] Length: 74 cm
fields.materials_techniques:
[coat] Silk and lace
[waistcoat] Silk, velvet and cotton sateen
fields.public_access_description:
Henry Irving (1838-1905) wore this costume as Doricourt in The Belle’s Stratagem by Hannah Cowley (1743–1809).  He first played the part in 1876 but later revived the play in 1881, with Ellen Terry (1847-1928) in the role of Letitia Hardy. The play is a romantic ‘comedy of manners’, with many interwoven plots.  Irving’s costume reflects Doricourt’s genteel status.

Irving became a professional actor in 1856, and learned his trade in regional theatres until 1866, when he came to London.  He joined the Lyceum Theatre company under the management of H. L. Bateman in 1871, winning great acclaim that year for his psychologically developed characterisation of the guilt-ridden inn-keeper Mathias in Leopold Lewis’s melodrama The Bells.  He took on the responsibilities of ‘actor-manager’ in 1878 when he assumed the management of the Lyceum, and remained there until 1902, enjoying star status with his leading lady Ellen Terry.   Irving produced a diverse range of old and new plays at the Lyceum, including Shakespeare, historical drama, and literary adaptations.  His tireless work to elevate the status of the theatrical profession was rewarded in 1895 when he became the first actor ever to receive a knighthood for services to the Theatre.

Irving specialised in spectacularly staged productions with large casts of performers. He commissioned designers and composers to create appropriate scenery, costume and incidental music, played by a full orchestra.  Although electric lighting was available from the 1880s, Irving preferred the softer effects of gas, with lime light to focus attention at key points in the play.  Irving toured complete productions outside London, taking the full company, scenery and costumes throughout the United Kingdom and across the United States and Canada.   The development of the railway system made his the first generation able to achieve this level of touring productions.
fields.bibliography: Holmes, Martin. <u>Stage Costumes and Accessories in the London Museum</u>. London : HMSO, 1968. Catalogue entry 54.
fields.credit: Given by the Royal Shakespeare Company
